PR aims to implement a basic support to field mapping ([Mapping](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/guide/current/mapping-intro.html)), solving in this way #11.

Considering the test provided in `operations/mapping.rs`, the index resulting will look like the following one:

```json
{
   "tests_test_mapping":{
      "aliases":{

      },
      "mappings":{
         "sample":{
            "properties":{
               "created_at":{
                  "type":"date",
                  "format":"epoch_second"
               },
               "title":{
                  "type":"string",
                  "index":"not_analyzed"
               }
            }
         }
      },
      "settings":{
         "index":{
            "creation_date":"1457142986574",
            "number_of_shards":"5",
            "number_of_replicas":"1",
            "uuid":"ymWlRAdtQQGtaqDBVJvdkw",
            "version":{
               "created":"2010199"
            }
         }
      },
      "warmers":{

      }
   }
}

I was wondering how I can set an index for a certain field. Basically I have an array of strings `work_roles` that appears in the following way

```json
"work_roles": {
    "type": "string"
}
```

and my goal is to make it in this way:

```json
"work_roles": {
    "type": "string",
    "index": "not_analyzed"
}
```

Unfortunately I wasn't able to find anything in the docs. Am I missing something?

extern crate rustc_serialize;
use rustc_serialize::json::{self, ToJson};

#[derive(RustcEncodable, RustcDecodable, Debug)]
pub struct Talent {
  pub id:                 u32,
  pub accepted:           bool,
  pub work_roles:         Vec<String>,
  pub work_languages:     Vec<String>,
  pub work_experience:    String,
  pub work_locations:     Vec<String>,
  pub work_authorization: String,
  pub company_ids:        Vec<u32>,
  pub batch_starts_at:    String,
  pub batch_ends_at:      String,
  pub added_to_batch_at:  String,
  pub weight:             i32,
  pub blocked_companies:  Vec<u32>
}

impl Talent {
  /// Populate the ElasticSearch index with `Vec<Talent>`.
  pub fn index_many(talents: Vec<Talent>, mut es: &mut Client, index: &str) -> Result<BulkResult, EsError> {
    let actions: Vec<Action> = talents.iter().map(|talent| {
      Action::index(talent.to_json()).with_id(&*talent.id.to_string())
                                     .with_index(index)
    }).collect();

    es.bulk(&actions).send()
  }
}

```ruby
def instructions(invitation)
  #...
  @sender = invitation.sent_by
  #...
end
```

the urlencoded crate and the rust compiler are versioned at the most recent stable releases.

**Current behavior**
`/?key[]=val1&key[]=val2` => `{"key[]": ["1", "2"]}`

**Suggested behavior**
`/?key[]=val1&key[]=val2` => `{"key": ["1", "2"]}`

**Currently supported behavior**
`/?key=val1&key=val2` => `{"key": ["1", "2"]}`

This topic doesn't seem really [clear](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6243051/how-to-pass-an-array-within-a-query-string) to everyone, but I'm pretty sure that the suggested one is the most common behavior (see Rails or PHP, for   // I'm just trying to compile this, it's the snippet inside the README 
  let query = Query::build_filtered(
    Filter::build_bool()
      .with_must(vec![
        Filter::build_term("field_a", "value").build(),
        Filter::build_range("field_b")
          .with_gte(5)
          .with_lt(10)
          .build()
      ])
  )
  .with_query(Query::build_query_string("some value").build())
  .build();

  let result = es.search_query()
    .with_indexes(ES_INDEXES)
    //.with_query(&Query::build_match_all().build())
    .with_query(&query)
    .with_sort(&Sort::new(vec![
      SortField::new("updated_at", Some(Order::Desc)).build()
    ]))
    .send()
    .ok()
    .unwrap();
}

-0,0 +1,122 @@
+/* This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public
+ * License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this
+ * file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. */
+
+vec2 SnapToPixels(vec2 pos)
+{
+    // Snap the vertex to pixel position to guarantee correct texture
+    // sampling when using bilinear filtering.
+#ifdef SERVO_ES2
+    // TODO(gw): ES2 doesn't have round(). Do we ever get negative coords here?
+    return floor(0.5 + pos * uDevicePixelRatio) / uDevicePixelRatio;
+#else
+    return round(pos * uDevicePixelRatio) / uDevicePixelRatio;
+#endif
+}
+
+vec2 Bilerp2(vec2 tl, vec2 tr, vec2 br, vec2 bl, vec2 st) {
+    return mix(mix(tl, bl, st.y), mix(tr, br, st.y), st.x);
+}
+
+vec4 Bilerp4(vec4 tl, vec4 tr, vec4 br, vec4 bl, vec2 st) {

JSON Api returns different types of results when fetching admedia (and I guess resources in general). 

Eg. When there are several results, the api returns an array of objects
```json
"admediumItems": {
        "admediumItem": [{...}, {...}, {...}]
}
```

When there's only one, it returns the result object itself

```json
"admediumItems": {
        "admediumItem": {...}
}
```"},"comment":{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/mozestudio/zanox-rb/issues/comments/179763037","html_url":"https://github.com/mozestudio/zanox-rb/pull/5#issuecomment-179763037","issue_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/mozestudio/zanox-rb/issues/5","id":179763037,"user":{"login":"RoxasShadow","id":805144,"avatar_url":"https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/805144?v=3","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow","html_url":"https://github.com/RoxasShadow","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/followers","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/following{/other_user}","gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/gists{/gist_id}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/starred{/owner}{/repo}","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/subscriptions","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/orgs","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/repos","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/events{/privacy}","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/RoxasShadow/received_events","type":"User","site_admin":false},"created_at":"2016-02-04T10:38:06Z","updated_at":"2016-02-04T10:38:06Z","body":"Thanks!"}},"public":true,"created_at":"2016-02-04T10:38:06Z","org":{"id":4722503,"login":"mozestudio","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/orgs/mozestudio","avatar_url":"https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4722503?"}}]

the beta app, currently we create thumbnails that look great for both the list and the grid, but when we tap and open an image, what we see is the same thumbnail that is shown inside the grid. I think the best way to handle this situation is to show a thumbnail that looks like the original one but it's smaller (we could compress PNGs to JPGs and resize them to the screen size, so that the image size is kept low and in the same time we can't really feel a compression+size). The original image will be downloaded when requested explicitly. P.S. I also think that showing a compress image (in terms of format and quality only) inside the web client would be great as well. For example I keep a huge amount of images in my owncloud, and would be great surfing on them without have to wait even more than 10s to have some of them loaded. **EDIT:** it actually works in this way :) Another option would be loading images progressively. the beta app, currently we create thumbnails that look great for both the list and the grid, but when we tap and open an image, what we see is the same thumbnail that is shown inside the grid. I think the best way to handle this situation is to show a thumbnail that looks like the original one but it's smaller (we could compress PNGs to JPGs and resize them to the screen size, so that the image size is kept low and in the same time we can't really feel a compression+size). The original image will be downloaded when requested explicitly. P.S. I also think that showing a compress image (in terms of format and quality only) inside the web client would be great as well. For example I keep a huge amount of images in my owncloud, and would be great surfing on them without have to wait even more than 10s to have some of them loaded. Another option would be loading images progressively.
